title: Before 13 February 2022, will there be a lethal confrontation in Iran or at sea between the national military or law enforcement forces of Iran and those of either Israel or a Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) member state?
preds: I am greater than 90% sure this will not occur in the next 36 hours. The only chance it does - in my humble opinion - is if Russia kicks off an invasion into Ukraine and Iran uses the chaos and international distraction to take offensive action against a GCC neighbor.

Iran is in the midst of nuclear talks in Vienna. Given the need for an agreement following up to the 2015 nuclear deal and the short timeline, I think the probability for something occurring before 13 Feb is unlikely.

First up, you have to acknowledge that Israel has in fact conducted attacks on Iranian shipping in the past (https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/iran-ship-mine-explosion/2021/04/07/c0af3e00-9777-11eb-8f0a-3384cf4fb399_story.html). Quite a few attacks, by some estimates (https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/mar/12/israel-bombed-a-dozen-ships-carrying-iranian-oil-or-weapons-report). Technically this was civilian shipping but you can conceive a situation where Iranian military personnel were providing security and became collateral damage for such an attack. Additionally, as Biden pursues JCPOA talks, there is a chance that Israel will intensify its campaign against Iran (https://apnews.com/article/donald-trump-israel-iran-iran-nuclear-united-arab-emirates-9835ba4644959e9cb4584ca999f49002), though that attitude may simply have been a reflection of the previous administration. That said, it’s a fractional possibility so I’ll put 0% for this.

Currently there are no signs for such confrontation. Still, I put 1% because an unforeseen event might appear out of blue. A 0% means there are no chances at all that a lethal confrontation will take place.
Should have updated more often, but oh well.

There have been MANY attacks against international commercial interests (mainly shipping, oil tankers) in the Northern Arabian Gulf and against US interests in Iraq/Syria since 2019. Despite those many attacks there have been only two major attacks against a GCC partner in the past three years - both of which are attributed to Yemeni Houthi Rebels - who are backed by Iran but do not qualify as a 'national military or law enforcement force of Iran.'
1) Sep 14, 2019: coordinated cruise missile and drone attack against Saudi Aramco oil processing facilities in Saudi Arabia - claimed by Houthis but assessed to have originated in Iran (denied by them, of course). 
2) Jan 2022: Three drone strikes, one successful and two intercepted, against the airport and fuel trucks in the Abu Dhabi, UAE. 3 killed. Claimed again by Houthi Rebels.  It is my opinion - based on 3 years of precedent - that Iran is comfortable continuing its proxy war against the US in Iraq / Syria, and against US partnered GCC countries in the NAG and Middle East. It will continue to use proxy forces it supports through training, weaponry, resourcing, funding, etc - but will restrain its national forces in order to prevent a proxy war from becoming an actual war. https://www.cnn.com/2022/01/18/middleeast/uae-abu-dhabi-houthi-yemen-explainer-intl/index.html

Iran allied Houthi group are attacking again this time killing 3 in UAE.
Will this mean retaliation on Houthi forces in Yemen? 
Could this raise tensions with their allies in Iran?
Could it escalate into some tit for tat involving Iranian forces?
All possible but the time frame means I will stay low
Costs are significantly higher given recent JPCOA discussions and economic activity.

Iran is 3 to 6 weeks away from having the materials for a nuclear weapon.  There hard line government is unlikely to get back into the nuclear arms accord.  So Israel will feel it has to take a first strike sometime in 2022, unless some nuclear deal is struck ( which looks unlikely as stated above).  Since time to Feb 13 is about one tenth of the time remaining in 2022, I give the odds of an attack about 10%.
Although Iran is aggressive, they'd want support from partners like Russia and China.  Feb 13th is only a month away.

Iran has pursued an increasingly aggressive stance both toward Israel and in the Arabian Gulf.  Although a GCC state is relatively unlikely to attack, Israel has proven to be more than willing to take offensive and defensive measures when provoked.

Highly unlikely any lethal confrontation would be an **overt, declared, and acknowledged** activity between the national military/law enforcement of either country. Also adjusting for time (as this only has ~1 month to go).

The deck seems stacked against an emboldened Iran, not only from maximum US pressure to (re)consider a nuclear spindown but also as Gulf countries warm to Israel and align against Iranian assertiveness. Also, as @kakiser and @TDHesslink mention, Iran would likely employ proxy tactics to execute an intentionally (or even potentially) lethal confrontation. A shift in calculus would likely come from perceived support from a stronger partner, like Russia, who at the moment is consumed with Ukraine and Khazakstan and would probably be annoyed.
The recent change in the Iranian administration lowers the possibility of a lethal confrontation

Iran typically works through proxies and thus avoids direct confrontation by its security forces, including at sea. Maritime incidents implicating Iran in the past three years have overwhelmingly involved civilian ships, and fatalities in those incidents are rare. There have been no incursions of GCC member or Israeli forces into Iran itself, and Iran has not been attacked by an armed national force since the Iran-Iraq war. The chance of a confrontation, much less a *fatal* confrontation, in the very short timeline of the question is remote.
The probability of Iran seeing a confrontation in their best interest is very low, as long as emotion and pride stay restrained, which is never a guarantee.
It does not seem on the cards now,

Iran will not enrich uranium past 60% even if nuclear talks fail - nuclear chief: https://www.jpost.com/breaking-news/article-689730
Iran says war games in Gulf were warning to Israel: https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/irans-war-games-gulf-were-warning-israel-top-iranian-commanders-2021-12-24/ But overall, adjusting for the package of time.

As long as the Vienna talks format is going ahead (slowly, though) and as long as Iran is eager getting rid of crippling sanctions of Western oil importing nations, it appears unlikely Iran would risk any potentially lethal escalation for the time being. However, it remains to be seen what the second anniversary of the deadly assassination attack on Qasem Soleimani on 02 January 2022
( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qasem_Soleimani )
will bring.

The current signals don't show that Iran gov might be willing to take a direct confrontation with Israel, knowing that historically Israel retaliates when there casualties among its citizens. Therefore decreased the chances from 50% to 20%. I think it makes sense that these estimations are reviewed periodically. In case a new event occurs it may require an update of the previous estimation.
As time goes by, I have to tweak my forecast downward. Changing from 20% (1 in 5 chance) to 15%.

Israel apparently attacked shipments arriving in a Syrian port that could have originated from Iran on 6 December 2021.  Perhaps the ship as in port to confirm ISR reporting or perhaps to limit possible collateral damage.  However, collateral damage could also be minimized by targeting another transport ship before it docks.  If it's correct that supplies from Iran are on board, it's possible that Iranian forces could also be on board.  While this is still a small probability, it is another way in which the criteria could be met.  I also agree with posters that reference JCPOA negotiations and the motivation for Iran to minimize confrontations and any destruction of a vessel as described above would be done in a manner to avoid attribution to Israel.

I am going to put this at about a 1 in 5 chance of happening. As the JPCOA negotiations appear to be going nowhere and Iran steps up its uranium enrichment program ("Iran steps up uranium enrichment capacity despite talks to salvage nuclear deal" https://www.france24.com/en/diplomacy/20211202-iran-steps-up-uranium-enrichment-capacity-despite-talks-to-salvage-nuclear-deal) tension is building in the region and Israel is making preparations for what may come next ("Israel pushes for better Iran deal amid military buildup" https://www.yahoo.com/news/israel-pushes-better-iran-deal-153933412.html; "Israel signals readiness to escalate Iran confrontation" https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/11/23/israel-signals-readiness-to-escalate-iran-confrontation; Israel and Iran Broaden Cyberwar to Attack Civilian Targets). There was an alleged killing of an "Iranian-linked target" in Syria by an Israeli sniper in October 2021. Though not meeting the parameters of this question, it indicates the increasing possibility of Israel acting against Iranian forces in Iran or at sea to protect itself. I am keeping the projection at only 20% because of the likelihood that Israel would act in such a way as to have deniability making it difficult to assign blame on Israel.

Israel signals readiness to escalate Iran confrontation - Aljazeera.com
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/11/23/israel-signals-readiness-to-escalate-iran-confrontation
Tue, 23 Nov 2021 09:57:25 GMT
78a9cc917fc829aaa60a0fc1524759af

Raising oil prices potentially could temper Iran's willingness for a confrontation on Iran's territorial waters or vicinity. Also for the time being there are no new significant military escalations in the area.

Iranian Navy and IRGC frequently interrogate vessels in Straights of Hormuz and Arabian Gulf however there have been no lethal confrontations in these at sea encounters. At least none that are immediately attributed to Iranian military. The use of drones without clear attribution to Iranian military or Iranian government decision making appears to be the most frequent type of violence that results in casualties in only some percentage of attacks.
https://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/8/418064/World/Region/Israel-blames-Iran-over-lethal-attack-on-oil-tanke.aspx
https://jcpa.org/article/new-houthi-attacks-on-strategic-targets-in-saudi-arabia-and-yemen/ As depicted in second story above, on land skirmishes Iran tends to rely on supported forces rather than deployed Iranian military forces. There is some indication Iranian advisors might be assigned to militia or proxy units. As this forecast resolves there will have to be a determination if an Iranian national military advisor confirmed to have participated in a Houthi attack on Saudi Arabia or UAE resulting in the death of a GCC soldier would be considered as an interaction between the national military forces between Iran and GCC countries.

Iran is still seeking for the US to return to the JCPOA.  This becomes less likely the more they confront US allies at sea.  For the next few months they will be on their best behavior. There is a chance of conflict because Iran has shown a history of responding when pushed by Gulf states.

Raisi is making some starkly unhappy noises in the UNGA, but that is pretty much the name of the game. In a more practical sense, If Iran wishes to re-enter the JCPOA it seems unwise to ratchet up tensions. Assuming zero sum reasoning, actors with an adversarial view towards Tehran may therefore have a different take on things, but as things stand I think it is unlikely they would act. I am a bit cagey about the wording of the questions, because the probability of an assasination seems (to me) larger than a stand-up firefight, but I will settle at 7% subject to revision if things change.
An uncertain geopolitical environment exists and a hard-line administration in place may create the unspecified possibility.

The GCC has been trying to stabilize itself as noted by Qatar attending the GCC summit in Jan 21 and the end of the blockade against Qatar.  However, Iran clearly does not desire solidarity among the GCC.  With preliminary negotiations over the JCPOA restarting, Iran could step attempts to prompt discord among the GCC in oder to show the JPOA members that Iran is the stabilizing factor in the region vice the GCC.  Among other tactics, this could include risky behavior on the sea or in the air to force GCC personnel into a hasty reaction that could lead to an accidental death on either side.

decrementing for time elapsed. nobody really wants to escalate. Saudis and Israel maybe but no compelling reason for why they would do so now.   That said its still a volatile region and there is lots of time left on the forecast for things to change

So some people have asked me why I'm so high on this question:
- The high level answer is that I just don't feel like I have that much insight into what Iran has been thinking. And honestly, I really haven't exhausted the amount of research I could do on this question.
  - For instance, I don't feel like I have good insight on whether Iran might want to escalate a bit to get better conditions on its return to the JCPOA (though most likely not). Also, I don't think that the base rate is 0. In particular, the US killed https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qasem_Soleimani:
- I think it was probably a good move, and it reminded me of https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_Luis_Carrero_Blanco, the prophylactic assassination of one of the likely heirs of Franco (the Spanish dictator), which might have contributed to Spain becoming a democracy sooner
- But I don't think that Biden would make such a move today. Or generally, Biden seems to be less partisan towards Israel than Trump, which might make Israel more bellicose (?). To make this explicit, if the opportunity to kill Soleimani had arised this year, it seems plausible that Biden would not have taken it, but that Israel would have instead. Relatedly, sure, the base rate of confirmed Iran/Israel engagements is low, but three of the most relevant leaders have changed: Trump -> Biden, Netanyahu -> Bennett, Rouhani-> Raisi. Then the effects of Afghanistan and the possible return to the JCPOA are difficult to predict. These two recent articles also moved me a bit up:
- Israel really worried about Iran's nuclear capabilities: https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/9/5/israels-alarmist-claims-raise-the-stakes-against-iran
- Iran feeling naval-ly adventurous: https://www.tehrantimes.com/news/465033/Iran-sets-foot-in-backyard-of-the-U-S In any case, I'm moving a bit down because a forecaster I respect expressed some skepticism. For a sanity check, 12% until question resolution implies a 25% probability per year (1 - (1 - 0.12/152)**365), and a 75% in the next 5 years (1 - (1 - 0.12/152)**(5*365)), which seems kind of right. @Kogo

https://www.tehrantimes.com/news/465033/Iran-sets-foot-in-backyard-of-the-U-S
> Only three countries in the world, the United States, China and Iran, have such a ship as Makran big ship, and today the navy will be able to be present in any part of the world using the Makran.
> Now, with this presence, the Islamic Republic of Iran has in fact seriously tested its operational-support capability for its presence in distant waters. The Makran big ship, which is the huge naval capacity of the army to support these missions and is able to sail three rounds of the earth without mooring once with one refueling, will be sent to such a mission only 4 months after joining the fleet of the Iranian Navy and proves that it can support any mission. Lol.
Raised 3 points on Israel's sabre rattling

Considerations:
- Use of proxies rather than direct confrontation
- Unclear base-rate?
- New president might do things differently
- Israel/Iran confrontations are surprisingly non-lethal (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran–Israel_proxy_conflict) Classes of conflicts:
- Routine naval attack turns lethal
- Retaliation for the assasination of Solemaini (https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Qasem_Soleimani)
- Escalation because of Iran's nuclear deal
- Retaliation for Gulf countries' recognition of Israel? ## United Arab Emirates
https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Iran%E2%80%93United_Arab_Emirates_relations
Both the countries maintain diplomatic relations with each other, having embassies in each other's capitals
They don't share a land border, but have some disputes about some islands.
Relations suffered a "huge decline" following the Israel–United Arab Emirates normalization agreement in 2020
Chief of Staff of the Iranian armed forces Mohammad Bagheri meanwhile said that their strategy towards the UAE would now shift and the UAE would be held responsible in case of an attack on Iran through the Persian Gulf.[16] The conservative newspaper Kayhan, whose editor-in-chief is appointed by the Supreme Leader of Iran, warned that the agreement had turned the UAE into a "legitimate, easy target". ## Kingdom of Bahrain
https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Bahrain%E2%80%93Iran_relations
Since the 1979 Iranian Revolution, relations between the two countries have been strained over various geopolitical issues such as the interpretations of Islam, aspirations for leadership of the Islamic world, and relations with the United States, Europe, and other Western countries. In addition, Iran has been severely critical of Bahrain for hosting the United States Fifth Fleet within the Persian Gulf at the Naval Support Activity Bahrain base
After the Saudi diplomatic missions in Iran were ransacked by Iranian protesters following the execution of Nimr al-Nimr, Bahrain followed Saudi Arabia's decision by severing diplomatic relations with Iran on January 4, 2016.[1] On 16 April 2019, a court in Bahrain sentenced 139 people to prison for forming terrorist groups backed by Iran. A total of 169 were arrested
On September 11, 2020, Bahrain announced it would establish official ties with Israel. The surprising normalization attempt by Bahrain has prompted anger from the Iranian leadership, as many Iranian officials openly denounced the deal and accused Bahrain of working with Zionist groups ## Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Iran–Saudi_Arabia_relations
Iran and Saudi Arabia have no diplomatic relations following the attack on the Saudi embassy in Tehran in January 2016 after Saudi Arabia executed Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, a Shia cleric. Bilateral relations between the countries have been strained over several geopolitical issues such as the interpretations of Islam, aspirations for leadership of the Islamic world, oil export policy and relations with the United States and other Western countries. 
In the Syrian Civil War, Iran has supported the Syrian government militarily and with billions of dollars of aid, while Saudi Arabia was a major supplier of aid to rebel groups. Both countries have accused each other of support for terrorism.[2][3] Iran and Saudi Arabia are both mixed up in the strive for dominance of their region
The major general of Iranian Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) Qasem Soleimani was assassinated in a targeted American drone strike on 3 January 2020 in Baghdad airport, when he was invited by Iraqi Prime Minister Adil Abdul-Mahdi as a mediator to talk about Iran's response to a previous message from Saudi Arabia related to normalization of relationship between the two nations.  ## Sultanate of Oman
Iran–Oman relations are bilateral relations between Oman and Iran. The two countries currently share diplomatic and economic ties dating back to the Pahlavi period. Oman considers Iran not to be a threat perceived by the other Arab states of the Persian Gulf.[citation needed] Both countries are members of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation, the Non-Aligned Movement and the Group of 77. Iran has an embassy in Muscat whilst Oman has an embassy in Tehran.
Though on two occasions the U.S. has dispatched high-level officials to discuss Iran with Oman, the fact that Oman has avoided publicly expressing any concerns regarding Iran's nuclear program is likely a reason why the two states have managed to maintain strong ties. 
In addition to strong diplomatic and political ties, Iran and Oman cooperate economically on several fronts, including energy. Most recently, the Gulf neighbors signed an initial agreement to begin supplying large quantities of natural gas from Iran to Oman, a project that was earlier reported to be worth between $7–12 billion ## State of Qatar
https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Iran%E2%80%93Qatar_relations
During the 2017 Qatar diplomatic crisis, Iran provided diplomatic and economic support to Qatar.[17] On June 5, the day that the crisis erupted, Iran asked the Arab nations to settle their dispute through dialogue.[18
After Saudi Arabia and its Persian Gulf allies blocked Qatar economically, Iran sent food supplies, amounting to 1,100 tons of fruit and vegetables and 66 tons of beef, to Qatar on a daily basis
On 26 August 2018, during a phone conversation between Emir of Qatar and Iranian President Rouhani, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al-Thani stated that “Thanks to the integrity and solidarity of Qatari people and cooperation and help of friend countries, especially Iran, we have overcome the issues of the unjust, cruel siege and we will never forget Iran’s stances in this regard.”
Probability of conflict: ~0% ## State of Kuwait
https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Iran%E2%80%93Kuwait_relations
Kuwait describes its relations with Iran as "excellent and historical". ## Israel
https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Iran–Israel_relations
https://www.wikiwand.com/en/Iran%E2%80%93Israel_proxy_conflict#/Attacks_on_ships_and_incidents_in_2021 On several occasions between 2013 and 2017 Israel reportedly carried out or supported attacks on Hezbollah and Iranian targets within Syrian territories or Lebanon
One of the first reliably reported incidents took place on 30 January 2013, when Israeli aircraft struck a Syrian convoy allegedly transporting Iranian weapons to Hezbollah.[133] Habitually, Israel refused to comment on the incident, a stance that is believed to seek to ensure that the Syrian government did not feel obliged to retaliate.[133]
Beginning in January 2017, the Israeli Air Force began flying almost daily attack missions against Iranian targets in Syria, dropping about 2,000 bombs in 2018 alone
In June and July 2020, a series of explosions targeted Iran's nuclear and missile programs and various other infrastructure. There were accidents and damages reported in the Parchin military complex near Tehran on 26 June, the Sina At'har clinic in northern Tehran on 30 June,[150] the Natanz nuclear facility on 2 July, the Shahid Medhaj power plant (Zargan) in Ahvaz and the Karun petrochemical center in the city of Mahshahr on 4 July. It has been speculated that Israel was involved,[151] and the damage at the centrifuge plant in Natanz alone could delay the Iranian nuclear weapons program by one or two years, according to intelligence officials
Israeli commandos carried out attacks which damaged numerous Iranian cargo ships carrying oil and weapons to Syria from late 2019 to 2021.[163] Israeli-owned ships were attacked in the Gulf of Oman and the Arabian Sea, allegedly by Iran.[164] Israel was also reportedly behind an attack on an Iranian intelligence ship of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps Navy in the Red Sea, which was heavily damaged by a limpet mine in April 2021
Overall, these are surprisingly non-lethal *** Overall, my read of the situation is that Iran is in a worse defensive position and doesn't necessarily want to escalate. Saudi Arabia and Israel kinda do want to escalate the conflict, but the US really wouldn't. Although the whole region is a landmine, the period is also fairly short. I'll start at 15% and go down as I investigate this more.
The Iranian military is still trying to upset the trade routes so there is a possibility of loss of life
Initial (very) tip-if-nose, to be revised. Expect tensions to be expressed via proxy if at all in near term, given Afghanistan situation.
I’m not sure how often this occurs, lethal confrontation, so I am marking it lower (along with crowd wisdom), but I am leaving door open for this to happen.

This is a tough question due to the use of drones, spies, and cyberwarefare which therefore give deniability to each Nation.   There has been enough activity over the past six months to suggest that it is almost certain there would be fatalities in the future six months - although the strikes that are carried out seem to try to avoid them.  Whether that occurs between forces of each Nation is a much tougher - and if it can even be proven.  Biden also looking at possibly resurrecting Iranian nuclear deal, though US recently issued sanctions with Iran not seeming interested right now in the Nuclear Deal. Wiki - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Israel_proxy_conflict#Attacks_on_ships_and_incidents_in_2021
On 10 April 2021, Iran began injecting uranium hexaflouride gas into advanced IR-6 and IR- 5 centrifuges at Natanz, but an accident occurred in the electricity distribution network the next day due to Mossad activity.
Israel was also reportedly behind an attack on an Iranian intelligence ship of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps Navy in the Red Sea, which was heavily damaged by a limpet mine in April 2021.
On May 23, at least nine people were injured in a blast at an Iranian plant that reportedly produces UAVs in Isfahan
On May 26, an explosion took place at a petrochemical complex in the city of Asaluyeh in southern Iran, killing a worker and injuring two.
On July 3, an Israeli-owned cargo ship was struck by an "unknown weapon" in the northern Indian Ocean, causing a fire to erupt onboard the vessel, although no injuries were reported
On 29 July, an Israeli-operated oil tanker was attacked near the coast of Oman. According to senior Israeli officials, the attack was conducted by Iran. Mohsen Fakhrizadeh, head of Iran's nuclear weapons program, was assassinated on 27 November 2020 in Absard. Israel did not take responsibilities but it is suspected they were behind it.  (Fakhrizadeh was a member of the Revolutionary Guard.)

The GCC or Israel requirement is interesting. I'd put the odds of a conflict with at least *some* state in the region much higher, but I'm not sure Iran would want to go after GCC state military/armed forces on purpose. Making it a deadly confrontation also lowers the odds, though I could see an accident that leads to a death.
I estimate the  prior of a lethal confrontation at 20%, given the new tension, it adds up to 35
More likely now. The World is distracted.

I assume such a confrontation would be the deliberate decision of the new President.
I assume that Iran will just gather weapon grade plutonium and work on 50 nuclear devices and perhaps unlike Kim III, Iran will be able to miniaturize the warhead.
So while Iran bides it's time there is absolutely no reason for Iran to provoke such a confrontation when it can act thru proxies like Houthis or attack using drones.
Apparently a drone strike over international waters qualifies and recently reported an Iranian drone attacked an Israeli owned ship in Arabian Sea

"Regional tensions involving Iran continue" well, there was always tension. Nothing has changed internationally. Yes, there is a new president, with a well-known background. But this - I believe - has more impact internally - be it to unite all sources of power for conservatives/hardliners, preparing/grooming for next supreme leader etc. 
There may be some chance if Israel attacks Iranian facilities. But despite the fact that their PM is also a hardliner, I don't think it's in either parties interest as such an event could escalate to an unforeseen consequences.

I've only had a few minutes to research this morning so my base rate is a straight guess, but I'm going low because I don't think there have been many lethal (to national military or law enforcement forces) confrontations between Iran, Israel and the GCC member states in the last few years.  Seems like the key players are trying to avoid escalation so they would avoid situations that might lead to such a confrontation.  The real risk of this is a miscalculation where a military unit finds themselves in a situation that leads to casualties even though that wasn't the strategic intent. That is always possible especially in a region where small drone attacks and such are relatively common.

I think the context of “confrontation” should be extended to include not only national military or law enforcement forces but also Iran-backed militias / other armed groups that operate under Iranian control. Also the term “lethal” should include other armed groups casualties, not only national military forces. On 29 July, the oil tanker MT Mercer Street was reportedly struck by multiple weaponized UAVs. The Liberian-flagged vessel is Japanese-owned, but managed by Zodiac Maritime shipping group, an Israelian company. The attack reportedly killed two crew members and Israel’s government formally accused Iran. Iran’s government has rejected the claim, but Iranian media earlier stated that the attack had been carried out by “resistance factions” in revenge for a 22 July airstrike at Dabaa airbase in Syria’s Qusayr region, attributed to Israel. On 24 April, an Iranian oil tanker off the coast of Syria’s Baniyas port was allegedly targeted in a UAV strike resulting in several fatalities onboard, although Iranian media later denied that a UAV strike was the cause.
The MT Mercer Street attack could be interpretated as an escalation as it is the first known public occasion of an Iranian attack at sea in response to an Israeli attack not conducted at sea.
If Iran’s or its proxies modus operandi has indeed become less restrained, will increase the probability of further vessel attacks and fatalities in the Gulf area, believed to be owned or operated by Israeli entities, and even third-country vessels carrying cargo linked to Israel. 
There is a high probability Israel will retaliate against Iranian military targets and Iranian proxies. Prime Minister Naftali Bennett publicly favors striking directly at Iran even for attacks conducted indirectly by its proxies.
The 29 July event could be linked to the installation of the new hardline conservative president, Ebrahim Raisi. With Iran under President Raisi being increasingly willing to seek confrontation, Israel is likely to ramp up and expand its range of measures against Iran and its proxies on Iranian territory and abroad.

I do not think it is the interest of Iran to engage in a conflict at this time, especially considering what happens in Afghanistan and the fact that the US will certainly be more willing to demonstrate the quality of its armed force after these events. Nevertheless, considering the history of the Middle East, I think every prediction has to be quite cautious and no event has a really low probability there.

Updating probability; looking closer at the points I wrote, I see that my initial estimate was way too high. There are actually very few incidents (in recent years) where Iran has operated with their "official" forces. They shot down an US drone and once Revolutionary Guard were filmed removing unexploded limpet mine from tanker, but that's about it. Like @Foci stated, they tend to operate through proxies.

If I was Iran, I would let the world news cycle focus on the Taliban fiasco rather than pick a fight elsewhere. Then, as stated in the excellent analysis by @ThR, I think Iran would operate through proxies.

* Precondition: confrontation must be lethal and in Persian Gulf/Iranian airspace/international airspace. Between Iran's national military of LEO and Israel/GCC countries (inc. Iran's enemy Saudi-Arabia). + There's been armed confrontations between Iran (or proxies) and Saudi-Arabia (drone and missile attack to oil refinery), also attacks to Israeli/Iranian/UAE ships (drones, missile, mines).
+ All parties are present in Persian Gulf.
+ Saudi-Arabia and Israel are both in ongoing conflict with Iran (Lebanon, Gaza, Yemen).
+ Iran's new president might need to strengthen his position by projecting power towards Iran's enemies since Iran has lot's of internal problems at the moment (economy, covid...).
+ GCC countries have tighten their relationship with Israel, for instance UAE has both diplomatic and economic relationship with Israel.
+ Iran's Revolutionary Guard is prepared to unconventional sea operations in Gulf and has executed those previously. 
+ There's already been recent lethal confrontation in Gulf, 2 people were killed in drone attack to Israeli-connected tanker and Israel has not (at least in public) revenged this attack. There were heavy fires in two Iranian tankers short after attack but is unclear were these incidents related.
- GCC countries (like UAE) have working and ongoing diplomatic relationship and frequent discussions also with Iran.
+ Taken into account several recent incidents in Gulf area, question timeframe is quite long, lot's of might happen before 2/2022. - Tensions are already high near this important oil shipping route, so there might be lot of international pressure to Israel and GCC countries not to retaliate Iran's recent operations.
- Israel could revenge recent attack by non-public means (clandestine operations, cyber operation etc.) which means no lethal confrontation (one that is publicly known) at Gulf takes place.
- Iran could also use it's proxies (done it before) in which case confrontation is not between "the national military or law enforcement forces of Iran", meaning this is not "yes" -answer. 
- Iran's new president might not want to engage confrontations with GCC countries and Israel since there are still a possibility to reach some kind of nuclear agreement (which could ease up sanctions causing Iran lot of economic problems and internal problems). I think main issue with this question is, that although confrontation itself is very likely, confrontation which includes "the national military or law enforcement forces of Iran" is not that likely. Operations could be executed by proxies or ways that are (at least in some extent) deniable like recent tanker drone attack.

Iran will escalate as the weakness of US is growing each day and this region for US will not be crucial anymore. At least until 13 February 2022. Such incident might bring growing support for Iran and broke the GCC frame cooperation as one or two of its members might try to gain on weakness of US and arising arab support for Iran being a connection to China - possibly a future global winner.

There has just been an election of a more conservative president. This kind of incident appears to be very rare and would be a big step. Therefore I don‘t expect that the new Iranian President would sanction such an incident so early in their term (all things being equal - the ayotollah has not changed). I could envisage lethal encounters between proxies or civilian worker deaths (eg in an Iranian nuclear facility) but I think that the chances of actual reported action resulting in official security force deaths to be low.
They don’t do those things there, just throwing stones and hiding

On land Iran’s prefers to use proxies to attack Israel by supplying them with missiles but retaining a plausible deniability if accused of aggression and avoiding the loss of its troops.
Iran’s air force is now outdated (pre-1979) and the chances of it procuring new generation fighter jets are considered slim. 
The one area where its personnel are involved in direct action appears to be with the QUD revolutionary guard and attacks against commercial tankers using drones, limpet mines while utilising fast boats with commandos.
Israel has been involved in tit-for-tat maritime skirmishes with both sides keeping their actions and reactions proportional to avoid an escalation.
Given the past record Ebrahim Raisi, the new President of Iran, who Israel consider to be extremely dangerous, these attacks will continue.
It is possible that the Royal Navy or US Navy might come into contact with the QUD force and cause a lethal action, but that is not the question.
I will suggest that effective policing in the Gulf may prevent Iranian commandos from causing a problem that would preclude action by the GCC or Israel.

I will give this a low percentage. Iran and Israel are coastal navys and the probability that either one will try to project sea power into the other's primary domain is low.  There is a small possibility that out of area operations result in melee.
The shadow war between Israel and Iran seems to be intensifying. But the shadow war will need some severe escalation to be military force vs military force.

I feel obligated to forecast this question since I suggested it. But I'm really pretty unsure. I don't think the GCC are likely to have a conflict. If this was going to happen, it would likely be with Israel. But the difficult part is attribution. If there is a drone strike or a bombing, they usually are not definitively attributed to a particular country, no matter what accusations are made.  My real concern here is an actual war between the US and Iran, which is what Saudi Arabia wants. With the Biden administration making the decision to not renew the Iran nuclear deal (they could have reactivated it day 1 if they wanted to) it makes me wonder if there are players in this game that are gearing us towards war. Short of open conflict, however, I think it is unlikely that any deaths would be clearly attributed to a particular country, even if everyone knows what's really going on.
